SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Andrew is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type two diabetes, and hypertension. He presents today with an upper respiratory infection. He has been experiencing shortness of breath, fatigue, and joint pain in his elbows and knees after doing yard work. He has no history of seasonal allergies and has received both COVID-19 vaccines.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are normal, with no fever. Heart sounds are strong, and lungs have scattered ronchi bilaterally, clearing with cough. There is edema in the lower extremities and pain to palpation of the elbows bilaterally.

RESULTS:
Chest X-ray: No airspace disease or pneumonia.
Diabetic labs: Hemoglobin A1C is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Upper respiratory infection: Suspected viral syndrome. Send a COVID test to rule out COVID-19. Prescribe Robitussin for cough and recommend ibuprofen or Tylenol for fever.
2. Depression: Patient is currently managing well with barre classes. Reevaluate the need for medication or psychotherapy in a few months.
3. Type two diabetes: Increase Metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Recheck hemoglobin A1C in four months.
4. Hypertension: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order a lipid panel and refill the Lisinopril prescription.

Schedule a follow-up appointment in four months and advise the patient to contact the doctor if symptoms worsen.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Andrea is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history significant for rheumatoid arthritis, atrial fibrillation, and reflux. She presents today for her annual exam. Andrea has been walking, exercising, and doing yoga, which has helped with her arthritis. She has not had any joint pain recently. She is still taking methotrexate once a week. Andrea has been experiencing palpitations, with the last episode occurring a week ago. She has tried meditation and running to relieve stress. Her reflux has improved with the use of protonix and dietary modifications, with no flare-ups in the past five months.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are stable. Heart examination reveals a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, regular rate and rhythm. Lungs are clear. Right elbow shows edema and erythema with pain to palpation. No lower extremity edema is present.

RESULTS:
Event monitor results show that Andrea is in and out of atrial fibrillation with conversion pauses. Autoimmune panel results indicate that her rheumatoid arthritis is well controlled with methotrexate.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis: Continue methotrexate 2.5 mg once weekly. Refill prescription. No need for rheumatologist referral at this time.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: Refer to cardiology for cardiac ablation to maintain normal sinus rhythm.
3. Reflux: Continue protonix 40 mg daily and maintain dietary modifications. Monitor for any issues.

Andrea has no further questions and the note has been finalized.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Albert is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and kidney transplant. He recently visited the emergency room due to high blood sugar levels and feeling woozy. The patient admits to not staying on top of his blood sugar readings and not monitoring his diet closely due to his mother's hospitalization.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient does not appear in any distress. No carotid bruits are appreciated. A slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is noted, but it has been present in the past. Lungs sound clear. 1+ edema is observed in the lower extremities.

RESULTS:
Blood sugar is at 162. Hemoglobin A1c is at 8, indicating elevated blood sugar levels.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Hyperglycemia: Increase Lantus to 20 units at night. Continue monitoring blood sugar levels and adjust as needed. Order another hemoglobin A1c in a couple of months.
2. Depression: Continue with meditation and hold off on medication or therapy at this time. Encourage the patient to call if any assistance is needed.
3. Kidney transplant: Kidney function appears stable. Refer the patient back to Dr. Reyes for management of immunosuppression medications and maintain communication between providers.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Jerry, a 54-year-old male with a past medical history significant for osteoporosis and multiple sclerosis, presents for an annual exam. He reports a stressful summer with traveling and adjusting to changes in the fall, leading to insomnia. He has tried melatonin, meditation, and stretching without success.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are within normal limits. Lungs are clear, and heart sounds are normal. There is some weakness in the lower extremities, with the right leg at 4 out of 5 and the left leg at 3 out of 5. Reflexes are good. Arthritic changes are observed in the right knee.

RESULTS:
Right knee x-ray shows changes from arthritis but is otherwise unremarkable.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Osteoporosis: Continue on Fosamax. Refill prescription for 1 tab per week, 11 refills.
2. Multiple sclerosis: Continue seeing the neurologist and taking prescribed medications. Report any issues or concerns.
3. Insomnia: Continue exploring strategies to improve sleep quality and consider discussing further with a healthcare professional if the issue persists.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mrs. Martinez, a 43-year-old female, presents with pain in her distal radius after playing tennis and hitting her arm on the net pole. She reports a little bit of swelling and pain when moving her wrist, but no numbness in her hand. She has a past medical history of allergies and takes Flonase. She has had a previous trauma from falling on a rake during lawn work.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Upon examination, Mrs. Martinez experiences pain when pressure is applied to her arm and when her arm is bent. She has tenderness over her distal radius and pain when her thumb is stressed and flexed.

RESULTS:
X-ray of the arm shows no fractures or abnormalities, appearing essentially normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
Mrs. Martinez likely has a strain and contusion to the muscle in her arm from the impact. As there is no fracture, conservative treatment is recommended. She is advised to use ice for pain and swelling, and prescribed Motrin 800 mg three times a day with food. If there is no improvement in the next week, she should follow up for further evaluation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Lawrence, a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for type I diabetes, congestive heart failure, depression, and reflux, presents with complaints of shortness of breath for about 10 days. He has noticed swelling in his legs and feels lethargic. He experiences shortness of breath when walking up a flight of stairs. He has had one episode of waking up acutely short of breath at night about a week ago.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are stable, and oxygenation level is good. No jugular venous distension or carotid bruits on neck exam. Heart exam reveals a slight 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur. Lung exam shows crackles bilaterally at the bases. Lower extremity exam reveals 1+ pitting edema.

RESULTS:
Chest x-ray: No evidence of airspace disease.
Labs: No elevated white blood cell count, no signs of infection or pneumonia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Acute heart failure exacerbation: Prescribe Lasix 40 mg/day, daily weight monitoring, and instruct the patient to call if weight increases or shortness of breath worsens. Consider intravenous diuretics if necessary.
2. Type I diabetes: Order hemoglobin A1c in a month, follow up with endocrinologist, and ensure a recent eye exam.
3. Depression: Refer to psychiatry for talk therapy, no medications at this time.
4. Reflux: Continue omeprazole 20 mg/day.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Ms. James, a 42-year-old female, presents with right index finger pain after a skiing accident last Saturday. She reports a pain level of 7 out of 10 and has taken ibuprofen without significant relief. She has not iced or splinted the finger. Ms. James also has a history of chronic constipation, for which she takes Miralax.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Upon examination, the patient experiences pain when the finger is pushed, pulled, and squeezed over the distal interphalangeal joint. The rest of the hand appears normal.

RESULTS:
X-ray of the right hand shows no fractures or abnormalities. All joints and bones are in the correct positions.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
Ms. James has a sprain of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP joint) of her right index finger. The treatment plan includes applying a splint to the affected finger and prescribing a strong anti-inflammatory medication, Mobic (15 mg once daily for 14 days). The patient is advised to return for a follow-up appointment in two weeks to assess healing and determine if hand therapy is necessary.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Cheryl, a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, presents with back pain. She has been walking for 30 minutes to an hour daily and experienced back pain six days ago. She has been taking ibuprofen and applying heat for the pain. Cheryl has also been lifting weights three times a week, including deadlifts.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are stable, and blood pressure is well controlled. Heart exam reveals a stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Back exam shows pain to palpation on the right lateral aspect of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension, and a negative straight leg raise. No numbness, tingling, or weakness in the lower extremities is reported.

RESULTS:
Lumbar spine x-ray shows good boney alignment and no obvious fracture. Labs are normal, with no elevated white blood cell count or signs of infection.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Back pain: Lumbar strain likely caused by lifting or exercising. Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, ice the area, and apply heat as needed. Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises.
2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 10 mg daily and monitor blood pressure readings. Refill lisinopril prescription.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mrs. Anderson, a 44-year-old female, presents with left shoulder pain for the past week. The pain started after a gymnastics class where she may have injured herself during a certain move. She has taken Tylenol for two to three days without relief.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Upon examination, Mrs. Anderson experiences pain with any movement of her left shoulder.

RESULTS:
The last x-ray showed no broken bones or fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The doctor suspects a joint injury and recommends Mrs. Anderson to take 600mg of ibuprofen three times a day for a week. She should also use ice or a heat pad to help relieve pain. The patient should avoid carrying heavy weights and rest her left arm for three to four weeks. If the pain persists after three weeks, she should return for a follow-up appointment. The doctor will consider ordering another x-ray at that time. If needed, the patient can try Advil or Aleve for additional pain relief.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Elizabeth is a 66-year-old female with a past medical history significant for depression and hypertension. She presents for her annual exam. She has been attending therapy once a week for the past year and has a good support system at home. She has been monitoring her blood pressure daily and taking lisinopril as prescribed.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs: Blood pressure and heart rate are well-controlled.
Neck: No carotid bruits appreciated.
Heart: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (stable).
Lungs: Clear.
Extremities: Trace lower extremity edema bilaterally.

RESULTS:
EKG: Normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Depression: Continue with current therapy strategies, no medication needed at this time.
2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily, monitor blood pressure, and contact the doctor if blood pressure starts rising.
3. Annual exam maintenance: Schedule a mammogram.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Jose James, born on 9/29/1957, is a new patient presenting with constant pain in his left shoulder and elbow for the past five months. The pain began after a fall on icy stairs, where he landed on his left side. The pain has been persistent and worsened when lifting weights. Mr. James has stopped exercising due to the pain but continues to walk daily with his wife.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Upon examination, the left shoulder and elbow were tender without warmth, erythema, or deformity. Positive Hawkins-Kennedy and Neer's tests were observed. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength, intact median radial ulnar sensation, and abduction to 90 degrees were noted. No numbness or tingling was reported.

RESULTS:
The physical exam suggests impingement syndrome of the left shoulder, which is likely causing the wrist pain due to the interconnected nature of the upper extremity.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient is diagnosed with impingement syndrome of the left shoulder. The treatment plan includes starting with physical therapy two sessions per week, along with any prescribed home exercises. If the pain does not improve with therapy, a cortisone injection will be considered. The patient is advised to continue icing the shoulder and resting as much as possible. A referral for Dr. Martha Rivera for physical therapy is requested. The patient is instructed to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Randy Gutierrez, a young child born on 8/10/2020, started feeling sick around supper time the previous night. Symptoms include a runny nose, stuffiness, clear mucus, non-barky cough, pulling on ears, and irritability. The patient has a low-grade fever of 100.3°F. Appetite has been variable, with reduced intake in the morning. The patient's older sister has been sick, and they had a play date with a nephew who had a sinus infection.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
The doctor examined Randy's breathing, ears, and overall condition. The patient's ears appeared okay.

RESULTS:
The doctor determined that Randy is likely experiencing a viral infection, which could potentially become a bacterial infection if left untreated.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. No antibiotics are prescribed at this time, as the infection appears to be viral.
2. Continue with saline mist, Tylenol, baby Vick's, and humidifier use.
3. Monitor for a barky cough; if it develops, give half a teaspoon of the sister's medicine.
4. Use Zarbee's for the stuffy nose, following the dosage for children under a year of age.
5. Avoid honey for the patient; use agave nectar instead.
6. For cradle cap, use regular strength Head & Shoulders, Selsun Blue, or Nizoral AD shampoo twice a week, avoiding the eyes. Continue using a soft brush and baby oil to remove scales.
7. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week.
8. If symptoms worsen, contact the doctor.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Kayla Ward, a 7th-grade student, presents with acne on her face for the past two years. She has been using Persa-Gel and washing regularly, which provides some relief. No associated symptoms such as itching, bleeding, or pain are reported. Acne is not severe on the chest or back. She has a regular period for about two years. The biggest flare occurred when she started school sports in the fall.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Full exam performed except for under the underwear and bra. Multiple benign nevi on the trunk and extremities, scattered skin-colored papules, open and closed comedones, and erythematous papules on the face, primarily on the forehead, central cheeks, and chin. Chest and back are relatively spared. The remainder of the examination is normal.

RESULTS:
Mild to moderate acne, mostly comodonal with a small inflammatory component.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Topical therapy: In the morning, wash face with a mild cleanser, use a noncomedogenic moisturizer with sunscreen SPF 30 or higher. In the evening, wash face with the same cleanser, apply adapalene 0.1% cream in a thin layer to acne-prone areas, starting a few nights a week and gradually increasing to every night. If not covered by insurance, try different gel over the counter. Follow with Clean and Clear Persa-Gel in a thin layer and a noncomedogenic moisturizer. Wear sunscreen when outside due to sensitivity from the topical retinoid. Expect some dryness or irritation.
2. Multiple benign moles observed on arms, legs, back, and abdomen. No worrisome features.
3. Follow up in six months to assess progress. Contact the office if any questions or concerns arise before the next visit.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Julia Jones, a 25-year-old female, presents for a breast reduction consultation. She has been considering the procedure for six to seven years. The patient experiences back pain, neck pain, and upper back pain since high school. She has bra strap indentations in her shoulders and occasionally experiences numbness, tingling, and nipple pain. She has a history of breast cancer in her family and is currently studying psychology.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Inspection reveals asymmetrical breasts with severe ptosis bilaterally. There is no nipple retraction or discharge bilaterally. No breast tenderness, masses, or axillary lymphadenopathy is palpable.

RESULTS:
The patient has symptomatic macromastia and has attempted nonsurgical treatments with minimal relief. She is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty. Her minimum required resection, based on a BSA of 2.65, with the Schnur scale is 1,792 grams, which should be attainable.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
Julia is a good candidate for breast reduction surgery. The plan is to wait until her insurance changes in July and then submit the necessary documentation for approval. Once approved, the office will work with her on scheduling a surgery date. The surgery aims to alleviate her back pain, neck pain, and improve her overall quality of life. The patient will be informed of potential risks and limitations, such as breastfeeding difficulties and changes in nipple sensation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Kelly Wood, born on February 15th, 1979, is an established patient presenting for a renal ultrasound due to hematuria. The patient reports passing two small stones last week and experiencing episodes of bright red urine for the past six weeks. The patient also experienced frequent urination and severe pain last week.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Abdomen: No flank pain.
GU: Normal vaginal exam.

RESULTS:
Urine dipstick: Negative for leukocytes, nitrates, protein, ketone, bilirubin, and glucose. Trace amount of blood in the urine.
Renal ultrasound: Right kidney measures 10 cm in length and 5 cm wide, with no stones, masses, or hydronephrosis. Left kidney measures 10.8 cm in length and 5 cm wide, with a 6 mm non-obstructing left renal stone. Pre-void volume is 533 mL and post-void volume is 0 mL.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
Primary diagnosis: Hematuria.
Secondary diagnosis: Chronic urolithiasis.

The patient has one non-obstructing stone in the left kidney. Since it is not causing pain or obstruction, no surgical intervention is recommended at this time. The patient is advised to increase water intake, avoid sugary drinks, and modify their diet to reduce sodium, oxalate, and animal protein consumption. The patient is provided with a handout detailing dietary recommendations. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment next year, unless any issues arise before then. In case of severe pain or bright red blood in the urine, the patient is advised to visit the emergency room.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Melissa Sanchez, DOB 9/23/1962, MRN: 5484367, had a mitral valve repair on 8/3/2020. She has a history of mitral regurgitation, atrial fibrillation, diabetes, asthma, and recurrent chest discomfort with negative cardiac workup for coronary artery disease. ECG taken on 12/26/2020 reveals atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular response and T-wave inversion anteriorly. She experiences occasional chest pains and shallow breathing, which resolve after a few minutes of rest.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Head and neck: No JVD detected
- Lungs: Reduced breath, but auscultation and percussion are clear
- Heart: Rhythm is irregularly irregular, S1 slightly accentuated, no S3
- Abdomen: No pain upon palpation
- Extremities: Trace peripheral edema

RESULTS:
- ECG: Atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular response, T-wave inversion anteriorly
- Physical exam: Overall stable condition, recovering well from surgery

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Continue current medications: Coumadin 4 mg, Lasix 4 mg, and Atenolol 50 mg daily.
2. Encourage patient to stay active and listen to her body's limits.
3. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 6-9 months to monitor progress.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Judy Gomez, MRN 869723, DOB 5/7/1961, presents for ongoing management of psoriatic arthritis. She has been decreasing her prednisone dose and is currently on one tablet. She experiences occasional pain in her feet, especially on days when she is more active. Judy has been taking methotrexate, which she believes has helped with her joint pain. She temporarily stopped taking it during her first COVID vaccine but resumed after experiencing increased pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Judy has some pain in her joints, particularly in her feet. She has good range of motion in her toes and knees. Ridges in her nails are noted, which are attributed to her psoriasis.

RESULTS:
N/A

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Discontinue prednisone and monitor for any changes in pain or bruising.
2. Continue methotrexate for joint pain management.
3. Schedule blood work to monitor methotrexate levels and overall health.
4. Follow up in three months to assess progress and make any necessary adjustments to treatment.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Diana Scott, a 100-year-old patient, presents with a new worrisome heart murmur. She denies chest pain but reports severe leg pain for the past month and occasional shortness of breath when walking too fast or too long. She also experiences lightheadedness and dizziness, for which she takes meclizine as needed. She has a history of swelling in her ankles for the past six months and has lost 10 pounds over the past year.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Constitutional: Elderly, no acute distress.
Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2, normal rate and regular rhythm, 4/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border with mild radiation to the carotids.
Neurologic: Gait normal for age.

RESULTS:
EKG: Sinus rhythm with frequent PVCs and an anterior septum infarct pattern.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Cardiac murmur: Likely aortic stenosis. Schedule an echocardiogram to assess overall cardiac structure and function. Depending on results and severity of aortic stenosis, consider ischemic evaluation or heart monitor to assess PVC burden.
2. PVCs: Asymptomatic, start with echocardiogram only.
3. Hypolipidemia: Managed by PCP, consider TAVR evaluation following echocardiogram. Statin could be indicated.
4. Lightheadedness/dizziness: Possibly related to aortic stenosis or PVCs. Start with echocardiogram and consider monitor if needed. Follow up in three to four weeks after echocardiogram to discuss results and next steps.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has been experiencing shortness of breath, watery eyes, and eye boogers. The patient has used a nebulizer and an inhaler for symptom relief. The patient denies any rash, nausea, vomiting, lip or throat swelling, and has no known history of allergies. The symptoms occur in various situations, including inside and outside the house, and around their cat.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are normal, and the patient appears in no distress. No rash or angioedema is observed. Faint expiratory wheezing is heard bilaterally in all lung fields. The patient's chest X-ray and pulmonary function test results are normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Newly diagnosed allergic asthma: The patient is advised to continue using the albuterol inhaler as soon as symptoms begin. A prescription for Singulair 10 mg daily is given to help decrease asthma occurrences.
2. Allergy testing: The patient will undergo skin testing to identify potential triggers. If unsuccessful, further blood testing and immunotherapy may be considered.
3. Follow-up appointment: The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment next week to perform the skin testing. The patient is advised to bring their cat to the appointment.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient reports experiencing back pain and pins and needles in the right foot after raking leaves in the yard. The patient had a similar episode of back pain three years ago, which resolved after a day. The patient has tried ice and Advil for pain relief without success. The pain is alleviated by a hot shower and sitting.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
The patient experiences pain when bending over and upon palpation around the L5 area. The patient's partner reports that the patient also experiences pain when standing up. Dorsiflexion is normal, and pulses are equal in all extremities. The patient reports tingling in the right leg.

RESULTS:
An X-ray of the patient's low back was performed, and the results appear normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient likely has a sprained low back. The plan is to prescribe meloxicam for pain relief and physical therapy to help with stretches and exercises. If the pain does not improve, the patient should contact the doctor to discuss the possibility of an MRI. The patient's partner suggests an MRI now, but the doctor recommends waiting two weeks to see if the pain improves with the current plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has had a non-healing foot ulcer for about two months, which has recently become red and is draining. The patient believes the ulcer may have been caused by walking barefoot on the beach. The patient has diabetes with a last reported A1C of around 10.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs are normal, and the patient does not have a fever. The foot exam reveals a 1x2 inch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, proximal to the fifth MTP joint. There is redness, drainage, and edema present, but no necrosis, odor, or bony exposure. The patient does not experience distinct pain when the wound is touched.

RESULTS:
An X-ray of the right foot shows no evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient has a diabetic foot ulcer. The plan includes ordering an ankle-brachial index (ABI) to determine blood supply in the foot, performing a debridement to remove dead tissue, and prescribing clindamycin (400 mg, twice a day for seven days) to treat the infection. The patient will be provided with a surgical shoe to wear for the next month to reduce pressure on the foot. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for two weeks, at which time another debridement may be performed if necessary. The patient is advised to call the office if any issues arise or visit urgent care or the ER in case of emergency.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Stephanie Morales, a 36-year-old female, presents with left ankle pain after slipping on ice and falling two days ago. She has a history of diabetes and high blood pressure. The patient has been managing her diabetes with metformin and a controlled diet. She has an upcoming ophthalmologist appointment for a diabetes checkup. The patient is also taking Norvasc for her blood pressure and needs a refill.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Neck exam: normal, no bruits
- Lungs: clear
- Heart: normal, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (unchanged from previous)
- Abdomen: normal
- Left ankle: tenderness over lateral malleolus and fifth metatarsal, swelling, redness, pain with valgus stressing
- Sensation and pulses: normal

RESULTS:
- Blood pressure: 120/70
- Hemoglobin A1C: 6.8 (previous)

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Ankle: Suspected ankle sprain. Order an x-ray to rule out fracture. Apply air splint and provide crutches for non-weightbearing. Prescribe Naprosyn 500 mg twice a day for pain control, ice, and elevation. If x-ray shows fracture, refer to orthopedics. If no fracture, progress to partial weightbearing.
2. Diabetes: Continue metformin and diet management. Keep upcoming ophthalmologist appointment. Order new hemoglobin A1C and baseline labs.
3. High blood pressure: Refill Norvasc prescription. Continue monitoring blood pressure and follow up as needed.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has had a non-healing wound on their right foot for 2-3 weeks. The wound was initially a blister caused by tight shoes, but has since worsened. The patient has a history of neuropathy and diabetes. They recently completed a course of antibiotics prescribed by their primary care physician, but the wound has not improved.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs: Temperature 98.1°F, heart rate 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 110/65.
Foot exam: 1x2 inch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, just proximal to the right fifth MTP joint. Yellow slough present with minimal granulation tissue, no surrounding erythema or cellulitis, no fluid collection, no necrosis, no odor, and no bony exposure. Vascular exam: palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses, no palpable DP or PT pulses, but Doppler signs are present.

RESULTS:
Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis (bone infection).

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Diabetic foot ulcer: Order an ankle-brachial index (ABI) to determine blood supply to the foot. Perform debridement in the office, prescribe collagenase ointment to be applied daily, and cover with a dry sterile dressing. The patient should wear a surgical shoe to take pressure off the area. No additional antibiotics needed at this time. Follow-up in two weeks, with possible referral to a vascular specialist if ABI indicates suboptimal blood supply for wound healing.
2. Diabetes management: Consult with a diabetic specialist to discuss potential diet modifications to improve the patient's hemoglobin A1c levels and support wound healing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, William, injured his right knee at a trampoline park a week ago. He heard a snap and experienced instant pain. He has been taking Tylenol for the pain, but it has not been very effective. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Blood pressure is high at 180/80. Heart rate and rhythm are regular, and lungs are clear bilaterally. The right knee has ecchymosis and edema on the lateral aspect, but no effusion. The patient has a limited range of motion and experiences pain with movement. He has a limp when walking.

RESULTS:
The right knee x-ray showed no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right knee pain: Suspected lateral ligament strain. Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling. Refer to physical therapy for muscle strengthening and injury prevention. Further imaging may be considered if pain persists.
2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg and order an echocardiogram. Medication modification may be necessary to achieve desired blood pressure levels.
3. Diabetes: Order an A1C test and lipid panel to assess long-term blood sugar control and potential medication adjustments. Encourage the patient to monitor blood sugar more frequently and maintain a healthy diet.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has been experiencing back pain for a long time, which has worsened over the past month. The pain is located in the lower back and radiates down the left leg, described as an electrical toothache. The pain is currently rated as 6 out of 10, but can reach up to 13 out of 10 when severe. The patient has a history of a fall from a roof 30 years ago, which may have caused a fracture. The patient experiences weakness in both legs and back, and pain is exacerbated by standing, walking, coughing, and sneezing. Laying down provides some relief.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vitals are within normal limits. No bony abnormalities, redness, or bruising are present on the back. Positive for pain to palpation at the L4 vertebrae. Pain is present with flexion and extension of the back. Strength is 4 out of 5 in the left leg and 5 out of 5 in the right leg. Reflexes are brisk, and motor and sensory functions are intact in both lower extremities.

RESULTS:
MRI shows a disk herniation at the L4-L5 vertebrae level, with associated nerve root impingement.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient is diagnosed with acute disk herniation at L4-L5 with nerve root impingement, causing pain in the lower back and left leg. The patient has tried NSAIDs and physical therapy without relief. The recommended treatment plan includes an epidural steroid injection to reduce inflammation, followed by a referral back to physical therapy to strengthen the affected area. The patient will follow up in one month to assess progress.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a former IV drug user who has been clean for over 15 years and has a history of alcohol consumption and smoking. She has been feeling tired at the end of the day after work but has no other known medical conditions. She recently had blood work done by her primary care physician, which indicated Hepatitis C.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- General appearance: No distress, no jaundice
- Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic murmur
- Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
- Abdomen: Soft, no hepatosplenomegaly
- Musculoskeletal: No gait disturbance, no edema

RESULTS:
- HCV antibody test: Positive
- Liver panel: Elevated AST at 39, normal ALT, albumin, and total bilirubin

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Hepatitis C: Initial labs are consistent with Hepatitis C. The plan is to confirm the diagnosis with additional blood work, including Hep C RNA and HCV genotype. The severity of liver disease will be determined by checking for fibrosis of the liver through a special ultrasound. Treatment options will be discussed based on this information.
2. Family screening: The patient's wife and children should undergo the same screening for Hepatitis C.
3. Follow-up: The patient will be seen in about three weeks to discuss the results and plan further.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has been struggling with headaches for years, initially occurring around menstrual periods and during stress. Recently, the headaches have become more frequent and severe, mostly on the right side and behind the eye, with a pulsing sensation. The patient also experiences ringing in the ears and occasional blurred vision. Headaches worsen during exercise.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vitals, including blood pressure, are normal. Heart exam shows normal sinus rhythm with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Funduscopic exam shows papilledema. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves one through twelve are intact, including normal cranial reflexes. Musculoskeletal exam shows normal gait.

RESULTS:
Pending MRI and further tests.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient's symptoms are concerning for idiopathic intracranial hypertension. The plan includes obtaining an MRI to check for any other contributing conditions, performing a spinal tap to evaluate and potentially alleviate pressure in the brain, and scheduling a complete eye exam with a neuro-ophthalmologist. If idiopathic intracranial hypertension is confirmed, medications may be prescribed to decrease pressure in the brain, and the patient will be encouraged to exercise and lose weight as part of the treatment.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, Jack, was involved in a car accident a week ago, where his neck and head moved forward quickly. He has been experiencing neck pain since then, rating it as a 7 out of 10 in severity. The pain is not constant but worsens when he moves his head. The pain is located at the back of his neck. Ibuprofen provided some relief, reducing the pain to a 5 out of 10. The patient has a history of playing football but did not have any neck issues during that time.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Upon examination, the patient reported pain when the doctor pressed on the side of his neck, as well as during neck flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral bending. There was no pain when pressing on the patient's back or shoulders.

RESULTS:
The patient's X-ray showed no signs of fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient is diagnosed with neck strain, likely caused by whiplash from the car accident. The treatment plan includes anti-inflammatories (Motrin 600mg every 6-8 hours) and a muscle relaxant (Flexeril 10mg every 12 hours as needed). The patient is advised to avoid straining his neck and to move conservatively. An MRI is ordered to rule out any concussion or nerve impingement. Depending on the MRI results, the patient may be referred to physical rehab or a chiropractor for further treatment.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is experiencing right shoulder pain for a few weeks, which started after working on various backyard projects. The patient has a history of shoulder issues due to a previous injury while playing baseball. The pain is more on the outside of the shoulder and increases when raising the arm. The patient also experiences pain when moving the arm and at night while sleeping on the affected side.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vitals: No fever (97.8°F), heart rate 62, respirations 16, blood pressure 116/84, oxygen saturation 99%.
Right shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness at the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints, good hand grip.
Neurovascular exam: Capillary refill less than 3 seconds, sensation to touch intact.

RESULTS:
Shoulder X-ray: No fracture detected.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right shoulder pain: Likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. Plan to order an MRI to further investigate and refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks. Continue taking Tylenol for pain management. If symptoms do not improve, consider a steroid injection for relief.
2. Sore feet and ankle joints: The patient is advised to try soaking feet in Epsom salts to help relax muscles and alleviate soreness.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Jackson is a 45-year-old male with a history of diabetes type 2 and mild intermittent asthma. He presents with right elbow pain for the last three weeks, which he attributes to increased tennis activity. The pain is located on the outside part of the elbow and is described as shooting, stabbing, and very sharp. The pain is worse with movement and better with rest. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and ice with minimal relief.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
1. Heart: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from prior exam.
2. Musculoskeletal: Moderate lateral epicondylar tenderness of the right elbow, moderate pain with passive range of motion, no palpable joint effusion, and mild pain with resisted extension of the right wrist.

RESULTS:
1. Right elbow X-ray: No acute fracture, bony abnormality, malalignment, or joint effusion.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Acute lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) of the right elbow: Rest right arm, stop tennis for 4-6 weeks, ice elbow 20 minutes 3 times per day, provide forearm brace, prescribe Ultram 50 mg once per day, and follow-up in 4 weeks.
2. Diabetes type 2: Increase Metformin to 1000 mg twice per day, check blood sugar twice daily for 2 weeks, order hemoglobin A1c, CBC, and Chem-12 blood tests.
3. Mild intermittent asthma: Continue Flovent and Albuterol as needed, refill Albuterol prescription.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
- Patient Angela has a history of kidney stones, hypertension, and diabetes.
- She experienced kidney stone pain last week and visited the emergency room.
- She believes the kidney stone passed three days ago, and the pain has subsided.
- Angela has had seven or eight kidney stones in the past.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Blood pressure: 150/90
- Lungs: clear bilaterally, no crackles
- Heart: grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur (previously known)
- Abdomen: no tenderness to palpation or CVA tenderness on the right side

RESULTS:
- A1c: 6.7 (slightly high)
- Blood pressure at home: 130-140/60-70

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Kidney stones: 
   - Order urinalysis and urine culture.
   - Refer to urology (Dr. Harris) for recurrent kidney stones.
2. Hypertension:
   - Continue 2.5mg Norvasc.
   - Consult with nutrition to improve diet (aim for 2300mg or less of sodium per day).
3. Diabetes:
   - Continue 500mg Metformin daily.
   - Encourage patient to check blood sugar before every meal.
4. Insomnia:
   - Recommend 10mg melatonin as needed.
   - Encourage practicing proper sleep hygiene.

Follow-up appointment in three months.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has been experiencing asthma symptoms, including coughing and wheezing, for the past six months. The symptoms are triggered by colds and exposure to cats. The patient has been using an albuterol inhaler (Ventolin) almost daily and occasionally wakes up at night needing to use it. The patient has had several urgent care visits and one emergency department visit due to asthma exacerbations.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Blood pressure: 128/82
- Respiratory rate: 16
- Oxygen saturation: 99% on room air
- Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no ectopic beats, rubs, murmurs, or gallops
- Lungs: Diminished lung sounds with occasional slight expiratory wheeze bilaterally
- Neck: Supple, trachea midline, no lymphadenopathy, no carotid bruit
- Hands: Strong bilateral pulses, no clubbing, brisk capillary refill

RESULTS:
Pulmonary function test results are consistent with a diagnosis of asthma.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Asthma: The patient's symptoms are consistent with moderate intermittent asthma. The treatment plan includes:
   - Starting Flovent 110 mcg, one puff twice per day
   - Continuing Ventolin inhaler, two puffs every 4-6 hours as needed
   - Developing an asthma action plan
   - Follow-up appointment in 30 days or sooner if symptoms worsen

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has been experiencing chronic back pain for a couple of years, which started after moving furniture. The pain is described as a sharp, stabbing pain in the back that radiates down the right leg and sometimes to the big toe. The patient also experiences numbness and tingling in the right leg and foot. The pain is worse when sitting and makes it difficult to get comfortable.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vitals are overall good. Musculoskeletal back exam shows no overlying erythema or ecchymosis. There is midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain is present with lumbar flexion. Supine straight leg test is positive. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at L4 dermatome. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.

RESULTS:
MRI results show disk herniation with nerve impingement.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient's symptoms, exam, and MRI results are consistent with an L4-L5 herniated disk with radiculopathy. The recommended treatment is a spinal injection with a corticosteroid under fluoroscopy to help reduce inflammation and alleviate pain. The patient will be monitored for their response to the injection, and the procedure may be repeated up to four times a year if necessary. The patient has agreed to proceed with the first injection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is experiencing right knee pain after a water skiing accident five days ago. The patient twisted their knee upon landing and has been in pain since. There was no popping sound or sensation during the injury. The patient has not had any previous knee injuries.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/77
- Neck exam: No lymphadenopathy
- Heart exam: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur
- Lung exam: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
- Musculoskeletal exam: Right knee with ecchymosis, edema, and effusion; pain to palpation of the right medial knee; decreased range of motion; negative varus and valgus test; negative Lachman sign; palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulse; no lower extremity edema

RESULTS:
- Pending right knee X-ray
- Pending lipid panel

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right knee pain: Suspected medial collateral ligament strain. Order X-ray of the right knee to rule out broken bones. Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises. Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily for pain and inflammation. Advise the patient to rest and avoid water skiing until further evaluation.
2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel for monitoring.
3. Health maintenance: Administer tetanus shot as the patient is due for one.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, Kyle, has had a cough for about three months, which was initially diagnosed as bronchitis. A chest X-ray was performed to rule out pneumonia, and a lung nodule was discovered. A subsequent CT scan confirmed the presence of the nodule. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, which is currently under control with methotrexate. The patient is a former smoker, having quit approximately seven years ago.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vital signs: Blood pressure 124/76, heart rate 70, respiration rate 16, O2 saturation 98% on room air, afebrile. Lungs are clear and equal bilaterally. Heart has a regular rate and rhythm with no clicks, rubs, or murmurs. Extremities show pink, warm, and dry skin with no edema in lower extremities. Swelling is present in the knuckles of the third digit on each hand, consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Pulses are intact in all extremities, and capillary refill is brisk.

RESULTS:
Chest CT shows a solitary 2 cm nodule in the lateral aspect of the right upper lobe. The nodule is smooth in appearance, and there is no evidence of emphysematous disease.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Incidentally found right upper lobe lung nodule: Order pulmonary function tests (PFT) for baseline lung function. Schedule PET-CT to determine metabolic activity of the nodule. Plan for video-assisted thoracoscopy to remove the nodule and a small portion of the lung. The patient will be under general anesthesia, admitted post-procedure with a chest tube, and likely discharged the following day.

2. Rheumatoid arthritis: Continue follow-up with rheumatologist and maintain current medication therapy.

The patient is understandably nervous about the procedure, but the doctor reassures them that they will have a support team throughout the process.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Tyler, a 56-year-old male, presents with difficulty swallowing for the past 4-5 weeks. He reports a sensation of something being stuck in his throat, occasional pain, and needing to wash down solid foods. He has a past medical history of diabetes and high blood pressure. No coughing, vomiting, or blood in stools. No significant weight loss or chest pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Neck: No swelling, normal thyroid, no masses or lymph nodes
- Throat: No masses, swelling, or redness
- Lungs: Clear
- Heart: Normal, no murmurs
- Abdomen: Epigastric tenderness, no masses or significant swelling
- Extremities: Normal
- Neurological: Normal

RESULTS:
- Diabetes: Patient reports taking metformin 500mg twice a day, checking blood sugars 80% of the time, and numbers within target range.
- Blood Pressure: Patient reports taking Norvasc, with blood pressure mostly within target range. Blood pressure in the office was 120/50.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Difficulty swallowing: Refer to gastroenterology for scope and evaluation. Start Prilosec 20mg once a day. Advise patient to chew food thoroughly and seek emergency care if needed.
2. Diabetes: Order hemoglobin A1C, kidney function tests, and eye referral for retinopathy. Continue metformin and follow up in one month.
3. High blood pressure: Continue Norvasc and monitor. Refill prescription as needed.
4. Schedule follow-up appointment in one month to review test results and adjust treatment if necessary.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Jerry, a 45-year-old male, presented with an ankle injury sustained while playing basketball with his son. He reported landing awkwardly, rolling, and twisting his ankle, resulting in pain, bruising, and swelling on the outside of the ankle. He has been having trouble walking and feels instability in the ankle.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
The doctor observed swelling on the lateral side of the ankle, exquisite tenderness laterally, and some tenderness over the medial deltoid region. The skin is intact, with brisk capillary refill and no malalignment. Jerry reported difficulty walking and feeling instability in the ankle.

RESULTS:
An X-ray revealed a displaced lateral malleolus at the Weber C level, with no evidence of medial or posterior malleolar fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
Jerry was diagnosed with a lateral malleolar fracture. The doctor recommended surgery, which would involve placing a plate and screws to stabilize the ankle. Jerry is expected to be out of action for approximately three months. In the meantime, he was prescribed meloxicam for pain and swelling, and advised to ice and elevate the ankle. The doctor provided crutches for mobility and encouraged Jerry to continue coaching his son's basketball team during his recovery.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Miss Edwards, a 54-year-old male, presents with a 2-3 month history of stabbing, shooting pain in the right cheekbone area. The pain is triggered by certain temperatures and sensory stimuli, such as wind. The patient has tried ibuprofen, Motrin, and topical treatments without relief. The pain episodes last from a few minutes to an hour and are rated as a 10/10 in severity. The patient has no history of multiple sclerosis, brain tumors, or migraines.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
The patient's facial movements appear symmetric, and there is no noticeable weakness. The patient can hear equally on both sides. Sensation is slightly numb on the right side of the face, and the patient perceives a dull sensation when poked with a needle on the right side compared to a sharp sensation on the left side.

RESULTS:
MRI results show a small blood vessel abutting and possibly pinching the trigeminal nerve.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
The patient is diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia due to nerve compression. The initial treatment plan is to start the patient on Tegretol, with potential side effects discussed. Genetic testing may be conducted to ensure the medication's safety. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one month to assess the effectiveness of the medication. If the pain persists, surgical options may be considered.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a female who injured her right knee while skiing in Vermont. She caught her ski coming off the lift, fell, and experienced a popping sensation in her knee. She was unable to bear weight and had to be taken down by ski patrol. The patient reports pain on the outside of the knee and a feeling of instability, as if the knee might buckle.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
- Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
- Lungs: Clear to auscultation
- Right knee: Edema and effusion, pain to palpation of the right lateral knee, decreased flexion and extension, positive Lachman sign
- Pulses: Palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulse
- Ankle: No leg edema

RESULTS:
- X-ray of the right knee: No bony abnormality detected

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Suspected rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in the right knee.
2. Order a knee MRI to confirm the diagnosis and assess for any additional structural damage.
3. Continue taking ibuprofen (600-800 mg every 8 hours as needed) for pain management.
4. Provide a knee brace for support and stability.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment after the MRI results are available to discuss treatment options and potential graft choices for ACL repair.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient has a history of multiple car crashes, with the most recent one occurring in February. The patient has been experiencing neck pain since the last crash, rating the pain as a 12 on a scale of 1 to 10. The patient has previously undergone therapy and surgery for neck pain and has been prescribed fentanyl in the past.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
The patient experiences sharp, incapacitating pain in the neck, with numbness in the left arm and right leg. There are spasms in the neck and body. The patient has limited range of movement in the neck and experiences pain when bending the neck forward and backward. No bruising, swelling, or lacerations were observed during the exam.

RESULTS:
The patient's X-ray showed no fractures. The doctor plans to order an MRI for a more thorough examination of the neck.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. The initial diagnosis is a neck sprain. The doctor will order an MRI to further assess the patient's condition.
2. The patient will be prescribed Robaxin (1500 mg every 6-8 hours) to help relax the muscles and alleviate pain.
3. The patient will be advised to apply ice to the neck when experiencing bruising or swelling and to perform prescribed exercises every morning.
4. The patient will be referred to physical therapy and pain management for possible local injections.
5. The patient will be given time off from work until the MRI results are available and further treatment options are determined.
